awd_abstract_narration: Vazquez  9308030  This applicant will extend experimentally his earlier descriptive work of avian wing evolution which led to the hypothesis that fore-limb coordination in flying birds is automatic.  The complex and coordinated pattern of extension and flexion necessary in the wing during powered flight may occur involuntarily as a result of the structure of the forelimb joints and musculature.  Such a mechanized wing offers an elegant explanation of how a fledging successfully flies in its first attempt, and the unfailing coordination of the avian wing during flight. It would represent a key adaptation in the evolution of powered flight.  This work will be conducted in the laboratory of Dr. G. E.
